data.profileText: (subsequently Benjamin Gardiner), a Representative from Massachusetts; born in Bridgewater, Mass., June 17, 1764; graduated from Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass., 1785; studied theology, but did not enter the ministry; selectman, Pittston, Mass. (now Maine), 1793, 1794, 1796-1798, 1801, and 1802; town clerk, Pittston, Mass., 1794; moderator, Pittston, Mass., 1797-1802; selectman and assessor, Gardiner, Mass. (now Maine), 1803-1808; appointed as the first postmaster of Gardiner, Mass., September 30, 1804, to October 1, 1809; moderator, Gardiner, Mass., 1804-1806, 1808, 1809, and 1811; member of the Massachusetts state house of representatives, 1805-1806; served in the Massachusetts state senate, 1807-1808; elected as a Democratic Republican to the Eleventh and Twelfth Congresses and served from March 4, 1809, until his resignation on July 29, 1811, before the convening of the Twelfth Congress (March 4, 1809 - July 29, 1811); accused of fraud, forgery, and embezzlement; jailed in Augusta, Mass. (now Maine), on July 23, 1811, but escaped before he was tried; went to Ohio and assumed the alias of Benjamin Gardiner; United States Army assistant deputy quartermaster general in Ohio, 1813-1816; founding member of Trinity Church, Columbus, Ohio, 1817; president of Franklin Bank, Columbus, Ohio; left Columbus, Ohio, after accusations of bigamy; circumstances and date of death unknown.
